comments:
Nursing 050 serves as an introduction to the roles of the professional nurse. The content of the course includes overview of health care delivery systems and nursing's multiple roles in those systems, history of nursing, preparation for roles assumed by professional nurses, and the philosophy of Penn’s School of Nursing. The emphasis is placed on assisting students to understand the nature of nurses' work and the nurse’s contributions to promoting and maintaining the health status of individuals and groups.

Comments about the course content varied. Some found it to be “somewhat boring” while others found it to be “very interesting.” Students commented that it was essentially an “intro class to nursing” that taught a lot of “basic things about the current nursing field.” However, even those who found it interesting admitted that it sometimes felt more like “busy work” than practical, useful knowledge that would relate to later courses. One student “really enjoyed the Alumni Liaison Project.”

Some students “really enjoyed the lecture” but felt that Professor Zurakowski should have given exams to ensure people would pay more attention and do the outside readings.

According to many studnets, this class was not much work; there were a few large assignments, including a few projects and one large paper. One student claimed that the work was sometimes “just busy work” and “not helpful,” while another said that the assignments were “interesting and valuable.” There were no exams for this course.

Nursing 050 is an introduction to the roles of the professional nurse. The content includes an overview of healthcare delivery systems and nursing's multiple roles in those systems, history of nursing, preparation for roles assumed by professional nurses, and the philosophy of this School of Nursing. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the nature of nurses' work and their contributions to promoting and maintaining the health status of individuals and groups.

Student feedback concerning the course was overall positive. Students complimented that the course’s guest speakers, readings, and outings to conferences. One student wrote that “the assigned reading was the best I ever had” as required reading for a course. Many wrote that the guest speakers were their favorite part of the class. While most students thought that the course taught them a lot about nursing and was necessary, a few wrote that the material was boring and mostly “common sense.”

No students commented specifically about the teaching style of Professor Kutney Lee.  However, one student stated that he liked that the professor brought the class “to two conferences--the IOM Future of Nursing Report, and the State of the School Address,” both of which were very “interesting and informative.”

Students generally felt that the readings were informative and interesting. Concerning workload, one student wrote that the course should require more homework or projects in order to encourage more active participation.
